title: Spear Phishing
content: Spear phishing is a highly targeted attack that uses personal information about the victimâ€™s role, organization, or recent activities. It is more convincing than general phishing and harder to detect.

title: Business Email Compromise (BEC)
content: BEC attacks involve impersonating executives, managers, or trusted vendors to request payments, change banking details, or approve transfers. These emails are usually well-written and appear legitimate.

title: Credential Harvesting Attacks
content: Attackers create fake login pages that look identical to real services. When the user enters their username and password, the attacker steals the credentials. These pages often come through disguised links.

title: Advanced Attachment-Based Attacks
content: Some phishing attempts include malicious macros, links inside documents, or embedded scripts. Even PDFs can contain malicious redirects. Always scan suspicious files or avoid downloading them altogether.

title: Verification Culture in Cybersecurity
content: Advanced users verify requests through secondary channels, check domain records, and analyze email headers. When dealing with financial or sensitive requests, a direct confirmation via phone or internal system is essential.
